pbi.title: As a user, I want a global CLI for backlog-chef so that I can process meeting transcripts from anywhere
pbi.description: Implement an OCLIF-based CLI that allows global installation and easy command-line usage of the backlog-chef tool. The CLI will replace the current 'npm start' approach with a more professional command-line interface.
acceptance_criteria: User can install globally with 'npm install -g backlog-chef'
User can run 'backlog-chef process [file]' to process any transcript
Supports TXT, JSON, and XML input formats
Auto-generated help text explains all options
'npm start' still works for local development
Proper error messages when files don't exist or API keys missing
Documentation updated with CLI usage examples

concerns: Potential complexity in supporting multiple input formats

risk_flags.message: Global CLI implementation with OCLIF may introduce significant architectural challenges in supporting multiple input formats and ensuring robust error handling
Potential breaking changes when transitioning from 'npm start' approach to global CLI could disrupt existing user workflows
Lack of specific performance requirements increases risk of suboptimal CLI responsiveness and resource management
Global installation may introduce challenges in managing configuration across different user environments and system setups

suggestions: Define specific performance benchmarks for CLI startup time and transcript processing speed to clarify performance expectations
Include comprehensive error handling scenarios, specifying how the CLI will gracefully manage invalid inputs, file access issues, and unexpected processing errors
Create a detailed configuration strategy that outlines environment variable usage, configuration file formats, and global/local configuration precedence for the CLI
Document cross-platform compatibility requirements, explicitly stating supported operating systems and minimum runtime versions for the OCLIF implementation
Develop a clear set of example commands and usage patterns to demonstrate the CLI's functionality and provide immediate usability guidance

risks.description: Complex OCLIF CLI implementation with multiple input format support and uncertain error handling
risks.mitigation: Create comprehensive test suite, define clear input validation and error handling strategies, develop detailed technical design document

risks.description: Potential breaking changes transitioning from 'npm start' to global CLI could disrupt existing user workflows
risks.mitigation: Develop backward compatibility layer, create migration guide, provide clear deprecation path for existing users

risks.description: Lack of specific performance requirements increases risk of suboptimal CLI performance
risks.mitigation: Define concrete performance benchmarks, implement profiling and performance testing, set clear startup and processing time targets

risks.description: Configuration management complexity across different user environments
risks.mitigation: Create standardized configuration strategy with clear precedence rules, support multiple configuration sources

pbi.title: As a developer, I want to add configuration support to the CLI
pbi.description: Implement initial configuration flags for the CLI to provide more flexibility in processing transcripts
acceptance_criteria: Support --format flag to choose output format
Support --output flag for custom output directory
notes: Future expansion could include more configuration options
Potential future commands: validate, analyze, config

concerns: Scope of configuration support might need more specificity

risk_flags.message: Vague configuration requirements could lead to scope creep and unclear implementation boundaries
Lack of detailed implementation guidelines increases risk of inconsistent configuration design
Missing performance expectations may result in inefficient configuration processing mechanisms
Undefined error handling could create inconsistent user experience with configuration flags

suggestions: Define specific configuration flags with their purpose, expected data types, and default values to improve clarity and completeness.
Add explicit performance requirements, such as maximum configuration load time and memory overhead for the new CLI configuration mechanism.
Include comprehensive error handling scenarios, specifying how invalid or malformed configurations will be detected, logged, and managed.
Create a draft configuration schema that outlines the structure and validation rules for supported configuration parameters.
Document recommended best practices for using the new configuration flags, including example usage scenarios and potential pitfalls to avoid.

risks.description: Vague configuration requirements create uncertainty about implementation boundaries and potential feature expansion
risks.mitigation: Create a detailed configuration schema with explicit flag definitions, data types, and clear usage guidelines

risks.description: Lack of implementation guidelines increases risk of inconsistent configuration design and potential future refactoring
risks.mitigation: Develop comprehensive design documentation specifying configuration architecture, validation rules, and standardized approach

risks.description: Missing performance expectations could lead to inefficient configuration processing and potential runtime performance issues
risks.mitigation: Define explicit performance benchmarks, including maximum configuration load time and memory consumption thresholds

risks.description: Undefined error handling may create inconsistent user experience and debugging challenges
risks.mitigation: Create comprehensive error handling strategy with clear logging, user feedback, and recovery mechanisms
